  ▪ Shared drive (e.g., SharePoint/Google Drive) with “Live → Archive” folders  
  ▪ or an internal wiki page with download links and version numbers.
- Restrict edit rights to Communications / Design Lead + Accessibility Reviewer.  
- Publish assets in both PDF (for quick viewing) and tagged‑HTML (for screen‑reader users).

**2 – Release Process**
- When a new version passes approval:
  1. Upload the updated files to the “Live” folder or wiki page.  
  2. Move superseded files into “Archive” and mark them *Superseded [Month Year]*.  
  3. Add the new version info to the **Release Footer**.

**3 – Notification Workflow**
- Send a brief “New Version” message via internal email or chat channel:
  - mention version number, key changes, and new review date.  
  - link directly to the hosted copy rather than attaching static files.  
- Tag relevant teams (volunteer support, design, training, comms) so everyone sees it.

**4 – Training Integration**
- Update the onboarding packet and training slide decks to include the new version number automatically.  
- Encourage volunteers to bookmark the *Live Framework* link instead of saving local copies.

**5 – Feedback Loop**
- Keep a short online form or shared note for staff to report accessibility issues or improvement ideas.  
- Review submissions at the next scheduled audit.

**6 – Annual Summary**
- Each year, compile a one‑page change log (versions, audit results, accessibility updates).  
- Post it next to the main download link to demonstrate transparency.

---

This simple rollout routine makes distribution predictable, traceable, and ensures the “single source of truth” always stays current—keeping every team member grounded in the same ethical communication standards.
